intro: Galium papilliferum, commonly known as the hairy bedstraw, is a perennial herbaceous plant native to parts of Europe and Asia. It belongs to the Rubiaceae family and is characterized by its slender, ascending stems and opposite leaves. The plant produces small, white or pinkish flowers arranged in clusters, typically blooming in late spring to early summer. Its leaves are often covered with fine, papillate (bump-like) structures, giving it a distinctive appearance. Galium papilliferum thrives in moist, shaded environments such as woodlands and stream banks.
